note: Some speakers use this noun as a Class 5/6 noun - i-orenji/ama-orenji, while others use it as a Class 9/10 noun, i-orenji/ii-orenji
Many speakers use "umntwana" (child) these days instead of "usana".
Utata can be used to describe any middle aged man or older, even if they are not your father.
Ootata can be used to refer to any group of middle aged men or older. Even if they are not actually fathers.
Note that most speakers use iTV in Class 9 (in-) for television
"malunga" is always followed by "na-".  You can also use nga- e.g. Le yincwadi ethetha ngethemba. This is a book  that speaks about hope.

"Ikhwele" is usually used to mean a kind of envy of someone which motivates a person to work hard so that they too can achieve the same things which they envy, meaning it is more positive than the negative "ubukhwele".
This is a rather archaic term for a bed, coming from the word to prepare a reed bed.
Modern term for a bed from "bed" in English and Afrikaans
This refers to the character of a person, not a fictional or typographical character.
"igadi" is often used more than "isitiya", especially colloquially.
This word has multiple meanings, and can often be translated as, "so", "like that", "in that way" etc.
"thi" has many meanings, and it can also be used as a generic tense marker as well as the verb "say"
This word has multiple meanings, and can often be translated as, "so", "such", "these kinds of", etc.
Often used in the context of "get to"
"sika" is used for things that are not growing (for example, bread). "cheba" should instead be used for something growing, such as hair.

"fa" should generally only be used for yourself or animals, as it can be disrespectful to use it for other people. In those cases, more respectful terms such as "sweleka" or "bhubha" should be used. Note the infinitive form UKUFA is also used to translate "death".
"sela" should be used for things that are cold, such as water. "phunga" should be used for things that are hot, such as tea.
Note with the reflexive Object Concord -zi- and the applied extension -el- this verb can be used to mean "Go by the self" e.g. Umntwana wam uziyela esikolweni "The child goes by itself to school"
Xhosa speakers also use the English word "i-date"
This is borrowed from the English "change".
-cocekile "clean" is the adjectival use, as in "Icocekile le ndawo" (This place is clean)
Khumbula is also used to translate "miss", e.g. Ndikhumbula umama. I miss mom.
"cheba" is used for things that are growing (such as hair). "sika" should instead be used for things that are not growing (such as bread).
"phunga" should be used for things that are hot, such as tea. "sela" should be used for things that are cold, such as water.
This refers to interest in something, not to financial interest.
Note the irregular stative form "lele" to translate is asleep, e.g. She is asleep - Ulele.
Note: qhubeka is the original word for "continue" - the additional -ek- is, however, becoming popular

Note: many Xhosa speakers now just use ibirthday.  Note the personal possessive comes immediately after UMHLA - so umhla wakho wokuzalwa - literally "day of yours of being born".  Also note that imini yokuzalwa is also used for "birthday".  Usuku lokuzalwa is another variation.
Usually only used to describe things like thick blankets, pillows, cushions and soft furnishings.
"phatha" takes an irregular recent-past tense and stative form of "phethe".
Can also be used to mean "lick".
Note:  the borrowed word vasa is also used for wash
Note that "sitting" is translated as "hleli", as this is the irregular stative form of "hlala".
"Sala kakuhle" can be used to mean "goodbye" to someone who will be staying where they are.
In IsiXhosa, shawuta often conveys a more 'quarreling' connotation.
Also used in the sense of "return something or someone to a place"
Note: send something or someone to a place will be "thumela".  In Xhosa "thuma" is often used when someone is sending someone to the shop and then is used simply as "thuma"
"Smiling" is normally translated as "ncumile"

This word is used to describe taking someone/something to a place. Note in the perfect tense form it is sometimes difficult to see the verb as it so short, particularily if there is an object concord as well, e.g. Bamsile kwagqirha? - ba-m-s-ile "Have they taken her to the doctor?"
An alternative form is "onzakala"
Note that "bulala" takes the irregular passive form of "bulawa".
Azi is commonly used in the construction "know how to" as "kwazi uku", very often used with object concords
Hamba does not describe the act of going to a location, it refers to the act of going in general.
"mka" is a latent-i verb.  This verb is used generally to indicate "depart"/"depart from"
"thanda" can be used to indicate something that happens often, or a tendency.
"xoka" can be rather rude, especially if used to an older person or someone commanding respect. A more euphemistic phrasing is "phosisa".
Fudukela describes a person moving from one place to another such as moving city, or moving house.
"bekelisa" should not be used for a person moving houses, for instance - "fudukela" should be used instead. Bekelisa is often used to mean "move out of the way".
This is a more serious kind of need than "funa".
Used when translating "put on" as in "put the books on the table"

The word "phila" should not be used to mean "live somewhere", "hlala" should be used instead. It is more similar to "be well". The word "phila" is an inchoative verb, so it can be used in the perfect tense when meaning "well".  When meaning "alive" it is used in the present tense, usually with the progressive aspect -sa-.
"hlala" is used for "live somewhere", not to live as in to be alive or be well - "phila" should instead be used in that case.

"enzeka" is sometimes used in the construction "into eyenzekayo" ("the thing that happens") which can be used at the beginning of a sentence to introduce new information, similar to the English construction "What happens is that..."
"phosisa" is a respectful, euphemistic way to say "lie".
"Urhulumente wasekhaya" is also used for "local government".
"usuku" refers to 24-hour day
"iintsuku" refers to 24-hour periods
Sometimes used as a noun in the isi- group, e.g. "Simnandi esi spinatshi." "This spinach is nice."
Most people use i-eropleyini for aeroplane.
Literally translates "to rob, being armed".  Ukuxhoba is "to arm" and ukuxhotywa is "to be armed" -iwe is the stative suffix "kuxhotyiwe" translates "being armed"
Legal case
"iimini" refers to 12-hour days.
"imini" refers to the 12-hour day.
Legal cases
"isele" refers to a jail cell.
Jail cells
Legal charge
"ugqirha" can be used to refer to a medical doctor or someone who got their doctorate in academia.
"oogqirha" can be used to refer to medical doctors or people who got their doctorate in academia.
"gwayimba" is used to describe the act of refusing to work due to unfavourable working conditions/pay.
"isilenge" is used to refer to a crane which is a machine used in construction.
"izilenge" is used to refer to cranes which are machines used in construction.
Monetary fine

Monetary fine.
This word can also just indicate "in the afternoons" with a more general sense.
"tshona" refers to the setting of the sun.
"phuma" refers to the sun rising.
"phambili" appears as "phambi" when it is modifying something.
The -el- verbal extension is often used with verbs that come before "phezulu" e.g. Culela phezulu! Sing up!
"canda" refers to splitting of wood.
Canda is generally used for "chop" but can be used informally for "eat"
These days many Xhosa speakers just use the borrowed word "iskin" using it as a noun in the isi- group, e.g. "Sihle iskin sakho." "Your skin is beautiful."
"ncwela" can be used to refer to cutting paper or leather into smaller strips, or even stripping/trimming a plant. Informally "ncwela" can be used for "bribe".
Used to refer to your brother regardless of whether they are younger or older.
Only used when referring to your younger brother
Standard meaning.
"phaya" is used to refer to something far away.
"kungenzeka" translates directly as "it can happen" or "it can be doable" and is often followed by "ukuba".
Also has the sense of "impact".
These days most people use "i-oyile" for "oil".
This is used to say "I have lost something" by putting it in the passive voice. See the first example.
"phezulu" appears as "phezu" when used before a noun to mean above/ on top of it.
Refers to any tin can
Although, "ukuqala" is just the infinitive of "qala" meaning "start", it is used to mean "first" and is preceded by a possessive concord.
"(i)za" is a latent i verb.
An auxiliary verb followed by the present subjunctive or the past subjunctive
"mbi" takes the object concord for all noun classes except 1a and 2a (which take "wu"). The initial vowel of the noun preceding "mbi" is dropped.
"mbi" takes the object concord for all noun classes except 1a and 2a (which take "wu"). The initial vowel of the noun preceding "mbi" is dropped.
The word "utata" is often used to refer to any man these days, not just to a "father".
"Mhlekazi" is a respectful term of address for a man who is middle aged or older.

Sometimes the initial vowel of "uku-" is dropped in the negative.

It means can in the sense of "be able to".

Also sometimes "ngaphandle".
"phakathi" is followed by "kwa" when it is used to mean "between"
"phakathi" is followed by the locative when taken to mean "inside"
After doing something very often used with kwa-infinitive --> koku-, e.g. emva kokuthetha naye - after speaking with him/her
"phambili" appears as "phambi" when it is modifying something.
Many Xhosa speakers now just say "ngaseright" for "on/to the right"
Many Xhosa speakers just say "ngaseleft" for "on/to the left"
"thabatha" has the same meaning as "thatha". It is mostly a matter of preference.

"soloko" is an auxiliary verb
Often followed by na-, Compare  "Bayafana" "They are alike" with "Bafana nathi" "They are like us".
"isikolo" can also be used to mean "university".

Similar to "ground" or "soil"
It also refers to the land-line.  Most people use "ifoni".
While ulwandle does not specifically mean beach, it is commonly used to refer to a beach.
"Molo" is only used to say "hello" to ONE person.
Sala kakuhle is said to someone who is staying where they are, if you are the one leaving.  It can only be used when addressing one person, otherwise use salani kakuhle.
Used when addressing two or more people.
hamba kakuhle is said to someone who is leaving. Can only be used to address ONE person.

Sometimes Xhosa speakers use "iingalo" (arms) to refer to "izandla" (hands).

Note that this does not refer to "class" as in "type". This refers to "class" in an educational context (e.g. one taught by a teacher).
Note that this does not refer to "classes" as in "types". This refers to "classes" in an educational context (e.g. ones taught by teachers).
Most Xhosa speakers use "itoyilethi".
"phela" means more "run out"  or "come to an end" in comparison to "gqiba" which is usually used when somebody finishes/completes something.

The formal Xhosa for "toe" is "uzwane" but most people use "umnwe", sometimes followed by the word for foot "unyawo".  In this case the posessive concord wa- will be used.

The formal Xhosa word for "toes" is "iinzwane" but most Xhosa speakers use "iminwe" which is sometimes followed by the word for "foot/feet" in which case a possessive concord will be used, e.g. "iminwe yonyawo" the toes of the foot.
This refers to a theatrical play and translates to "game of the stage" which used to be used for "theatrical performance/play" but these days most people just say "ishow" for a theatrical "play"

Used in the sense of "let fall" not "drop prices" which would be "thoba amaxabiso"
This is the original form of "qhubekeka", however "qhubekeka" is now becoming more popular. "Qhubeka" is often followed by the subjunctive, or by na- "continue with".
Can be used with -na- to indicate being angry, e.g. Ndinomsindo. Literally "I have anger". Do not confuse with the Zulu meaning of umsindo being "noise".

Although "iqanda" comes from the word for egg, it is also used for ZERO - like the French "l'œuf" (the egg) which we hear as LOVE in tennis matches

Also used to translate "go from", as in "this train goes from Cape Town to Simonstown" "Le treyini isuka eKapa isiya eSimonstown". In its infinitive form it can be used for time spans, e.g. From Monday to Friday: Ukusuka ngoMvulo ukuya ngoLwesihlanu.
"hleli", the irregular stative of hlala, generally translates "staying" or "sitting"
